sense.name: intellectual understanding, appreciation of something
sense.examples: The author displays an amazing grasp of European history. The reporter's grasp of particle physics was next to zilch. Both candidates showed a grasp of issues that were foremost on voters' minds. Mary has a reasonable grasp of basic French.

sense.name: an achievement that is possible
sense.commentary: GRASP[+state][+hypothetical][+achievement] Note: a metaphoric extension of Sense 4
sense.examples: He knew then that success was within his grasp. Home ownership is well beyond the grasp of this socioeconomic group.

sense.name: a state of control, power
sense.commentary: GRASP[+state][+power][+control] Note: a metaphoric extension of Sense 4
sense.examples: An all-consuming jealousy held her in its grasp. The manager couldn't keep a grasp on all the crises happening at work.

sense.name: physically holding or clutching something
sense.examples: The vase slipped from her grasp and crashed to the floor. The man's handshake was a knuckle-crushing grasp.
